summary: This 1952 West Africa Court of Appeal decision in Kofi Anane v. Kwasi Brafo addresses jurisdictional limits between the Supreme Court and Native Courts in Ashanti, Ghana, concerning succession disputes. The appellant, Kofi Anane, obtained letters of administration for the estate of Kwaku Sampaney (alias Kwasi Brafo) and sued the respondent to recover personal property, claiming both as administrator and as successor under native customary law. The trial court halted proceedings, referring the matter to the Native Court under section 35 of the Native Courts (Ashanti) Ordinance, which grants Native Courts jurisdiction over succession matters. The appellant argued that his grant of administration established his status as successor and that the Supreme Court had concurrent jurisdiction under section 14 of the Courts Ordinance. The appellate court rejected this, affirming that a grant of administration does not equate to being the customary law successor and that disputes over succession must be resolved by Native Courts. The appeal was dismissed, upholding the principle that even where jurisdiction exists, the Supreme Court must refrain from exercising it in civil matters falling under Native Court jurisdiction per section 17 of the Courts Ordinance.

jurisdiction.court: West Africa Court of Appeal, Gold Coast

rationaleHighlights: A grant of letters of administration does not establish or preclude a person's status as successor under native customary law.
Where a plaintiff claims as successor under customary law, the issue of succession must be determined by the Native Court.
Section 17 of the Courts Ordinance prohibits the Supreme Court from exercising jurisdiction in civil matters within the jurisdiction of Native Courts under section 35.
The Supreme Court has jurisdiction under section 14 but is barred from exercising it in this case by section 17.
The trial judge correctly referred the matter to the Native Court for determination of succession.
The claimant bears the burden of proving succession when asserting rights under customary law.
Precedents such as Hagan v. Adum and Ababio v. Ackumpong support the remittal of succession disputes to Native Courts.
